references: Campbell, R. W., N. K. Dawe, I. McTaggart-Cowan, J. M. Cooper, and G. W. Kaiser. 1997. The birds of British Columbia, Vol. 3: passerines-flycatchers through vireos. R. Br. Columbia Mus. Victoria.

James, Ross D. 1998. Blue-headed Vireo (Vireo solitarius), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/379
Garrett, K. and J. Dunn. 1981. Birds of southern California: status and distribution. Los Angeles Audubon Soc. Los Angeles, CA.

Csuti, B., A. J. Kimerling, T. A. O'Neil, M. M. Shaughnessy, E. P. Gaines, and M. M. P. Huso. 1997. Atlas of Oregon wildlife: distribution, habitat, and natural history. Oregon State Univ. Press, Corvallis.
Anderson, S. H. 1970. The avifaunal composition of Oregon white oak stands. Condor 72:417-423.
Curson, D. R. and C. B. Goguen. 1998. Plumbeous Vireo (Vireo plumbeus). in The birds of North America, no. 366. (Poole, A. and F. Gill, Eds.) The Birds of North America, Inc. Philadelphia, PA.

Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.
Mannon, R. W. and E. C. Meslow. 1984. Bird populations and vegetation characteristics in managed and old-growth forests, northeastern Oregon. J. Wildl. Manage. 48:1219-1238.
Norris, L. L. 1986. Nesting of the Plumbeous Solitary Vireo in the southern Sierra Nevada. West. Birds 17:37-39.
Howell, S. N. G. and S. Webb. 1995. A guide to the birds of Mexico and Northern Central America. Oxford Univ. Press, New York.
Beedy, E.C. 1981. Bird communities and forest structure in the Sierra Nevada of California. Condor 83:97-105.

Goguen, Christopher B. and David R. Curson. 2002. Cassin's Vireo (Vireo cassinii), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/615.

Smith, M. R., P. W. Mattocks, Jr., and K. M. Cassidy. 1997. Breeding birds of Washington State. in Washington State gap analysis-final report. Vol. 4 (Cassidy, K. M., C. E. Grue, M. R. Smith, and K. M. Dvornich, Eds.) Seattle Audubon Soc. Publ. in Zool. no. 1, Seattle, WA.

Tewkesbury, J. J., T. E. Martin, S. J. Hejl, T. S. Redman, and F. J. Wheeler. 1999. Cowbirds in a western valley: effects of landscape structure, vegetation and host density. Stud. Avian Biol. 18:23-33.
Lehman, P. E. 1994. The birds of Santa Barbara County, California. Vertebr. Mus. Univ. of California, Santa Barbara.
Roberson, D. and C. Tenney. 1993. Atlas of the breeding birds of Monterey County, California. Monterey Peninsula Audubon Soc, Carmel, CA.
Small, A. 1994. California birds: their status and distribution. Ibis Publ. Co. Vista, CA.
habitat_description:
Southwest/Northwest:
This species' breeding occurs mostly in ponderosa pine, and montane habitats (hardwood, hardwood-conifer, mixed conifer) (Kucera from Zeiner et al. 1990). The species also occurs in forested wetlands, mixed woodlands, chaparral, and riparian areas (NatureServe 2004).
Occupies coniferous, mixed-coniferous/deciduous, and deciduous forests in mountains and foothills at elevations from 120 to 2,400 m in southern part of its range, and sea level to 1,200 m in the north (Small 1994, Campbell et al. 1997, Am. Ornithol. Union 1998). More often associated with deciduous habitats than closely related Blue-headed and Plumbeous vireos (Curson and Goguen 1998, James 1998). Inhabits mixed-coniferous/deciduous forests in all parts of range, but found mostly in deciduous-dominated habitats, particularly oak (Quercus) in coastal regions, and coniferous habitats of the Transition Zone, particularly ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa) and Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), in the interior. Tends to prefer dry, open forests. In coastal British Columbia, most numerous in open stands of Douglas fir, oak, and madrone (Arbutus) on drier, rocky sites, and in mixed woods of maple (Acer), alder (Alnus), cottonwood (Populus), Pacific dogwood (Cornus nuttallii), Douglas fir, and western redcedar (Thuja plicata); breeds in younger, secondary growth forest as well as mature forest (Campbell et al. 1997). More common in rain-shadowed forests of ne. Olympic Peninsula, WA, than the wetter forests over most of the Peninsula; in Cascades and Puget Sound region of Washington, occurs mostly in drier coniferous forests (Smith et al. 1997). Inhabits oak woodland in w. Oregon (Anderson 1970) and open mixed-deciduous oak and oak-conifer habitats in w. California (Rober-son and Tenney 1993, Small 1994, Santa Clara Co. Breeding Bird Atlas [BBA] unpubl.). In Sierra Nevada, CA, more common in ponderosa pine and mixed-conifer/oak than in lodgepole pine (P. contorta) and fir (Abies; Beedy 1981, K. Purcell unpubl.). In northern interior portion of range (42–52°N), typically breeds in Douglas fir-ponderosa pine, and also in larch (Larix), lodgepole pine and aspen (Populus; Campbell et al. 1997, Csuti et al. 1997, Smith et al. 1997, Tewkesbury et al. 1999). In Douglas fir-ponderosa pine in ne. Oregon, abundance similar in thinned stands and old growth (Mannon and Meslow 1984). In Baja California Sur, breeds in pine-oak and thorn forest (Howell and Webb 1995). Inhabits deciduous riparian woodland throughout its range (Small 1994, Campbell et al. 1997, Csuti et al. 1997), including oak and cottonwood in California (Garrett and Dunn 1981, Lehman 1994), and cottonwood-dogwood and aspen-dogwood in Montana (Tewkesbury et al. 1999). In British Columbia, breeds also in suburban habitats (Campbell et al. 1997). In s. Sierra Nevada, Cassin’s Vireo occupies cool, mesic, mixed-conifer forest on western slope at 1,500–2,000 m, and Plumbeous Vireo breeds in warmer, more arid piñon habitat on eastern slope, at same altitude (Norris 1986)(quoted directly from Goguen and Curson 2002).
